alert.note: Alert for Mora; San Miguel (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued September 10 at 4:06PM MDT until September 10 at 7:15PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Southwestern Mora County in northeastern New Mexico... Northwestern San Miguel County in northeastern New Mexico... * Until 715 PM MDT. * At 406 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated nearly stationary thunderstorms between Tererro and Cowles producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 0.75 and 1.5 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Cowles and Tererro. This includes the following highways... State Road 63 between Mile Markers 9 and 25. This includes the following recreation areas... Field Tract Campground, Holy Ghost Campground, Iron Gate Campground, Jacks Creek Campground, Panchuela Campground, Willow Creek Campground, Bert Clancy Wildlife Area and Mora River Picnic Area. This includes the following streams and drainages... Pecos River / Sawyer Creek, Rio Mora, Las Trampas, Rito, Jacks Creek, Perro, Rito, Carpenter Creek, Valdez, Rio, Panchuela Creek, Wild Horse Creek, Cow Creek, Soldier Creek, South Fork Bear Creek, Willow Creek, Into Pecos River, Cave Creek, Doctor Creek, El Macho Creek, Indian Creek, Holy Ghost Creek, Pecos River and Bear Creek. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Both localized and distant heavy rainfall will create sudden and dangerous flows in arroyos and over low water crossings.
